partner.label: Partner
partner.description: Do you have a partner? If unchecked, all partner related parameters will be ignored

calculate_til.label: Simulation End Year
calculate_til.description: Final year for simulation. Recommended value: birth year + 90

user_jobs.label: Your Total Income (in $1000s)
user_jobs.description:
Each row is a different period of time. 
 Start date of each is assumed to be the last date of the previous row.
 Employment gaps should be represented as 0 income.
 Try to optimize: The optimization algorithm will try to reduce the end date of this row by finding a good parameter combination.
 Social Security Eligible: Confirm if this income makes payments to social security (generally any job without a pension)

partner_jobs.label: Partner's Total Income (in $1000s)
partner_jobs.description:
Each row is a different period of time. 
 Start date of each is assumed to be the last date of the previous row.
 Employment gaps should be represented as 0 income.
 Try to optimize: The optimization algorithm will try to reduce the end date of this row by finding a good parameter combination.
 Social Security Eligible: Confirm if this income makes payments to social security (generally any job without a pension)

retirement_spending_change.label: Spending Change in Retirement (% of Current Spending)
retirement_spending_change.description: Many people decrease spending in retirement. A value of -0.15 decreases spending by 15% once neither you nor your partner are earning income.

drawdown_tax_rate.label: Drawdown Tax Rate
drawdown_tax_rate.description: Assumed average rate of tax on portfolio drawdown. 15% and 20% are the marginal capital gains rates, but the average rate will depend on your mix of tax-advantaged accounts at the point of retirement.

kid_birth_years.label: Children Birth Years
kid_birth_years.description: Each child is modeled to produce an additional cost for 22 years after birth

cost_of_kid.label: Cost of Each Child (% Spending)
cost_of_kid.description:
Estimate for average cost of kid as a percentage of spending.
 A value of 0.12 increases spending by 12% for each child for 22 years after their birth.

spending_method.label: Spending Adjustment Method
spending_method.description:
Controls how spending changes each year.
 Inflation-only: increases spending by the inflation rate for that year.
 Ceil-floor allows spending to increase when market returns are higher than expected, while lower than expected market returns require decreased spending.

allowed_fluctuation.label: Ceiling-Floor Fluctuation (% of Spending)
allowed_fluctuation.description: If using the ceil-floor method of spending, spending fluctuates by +/-5% (for value of 0.05) depending on market returns.

allocation_method.label: Portfolio Allocation Method
allocation_method.description:
Equity / Bond allocation. 
 Life Cycle: uses the lifecycle investing method of 100% equities allocation until equity target met.
 Flat: Keeps a constant ratio between bonds and equities.
 x minus age: equity allocation decreases with age linearly (120 minus age: at age 40, equity allocation is 80%).
 Bond tent: increase bonds till peak year, decrease bonds afterwards.

real_estate_equity_ratio.label: Real Estate Ratio
real_estate_equity_ratio.description:
Ratio of real estate within equity allocation.
 If value set to 0.5, but bonds are 20%, allocation will be 40% real estate, 40% stock, 20% bonds.

equity_target.label: Equity Target
equity_target.description: When using lifecycle allocation or net-worth targets for social security, this value acts as a pivot point for the portfolio. If set to 1500 and using lifecycle allocation, portfolio will be in 100% equities until net worth hits $1.5M in today's dollars, then any additonal net worth will be invested in bonds. To learn more, read about lifecycle investing: https://www.lifecycleinvesting.net/, but know this method does not use leverage.

annuities_instead_of_bonds.label: Annuities Instead of Bonds?
annuities_instead_of_bonds.description: Money that would be invested into bonds is instead invested in an annuity.

flat_bond_target.label: Flat Bond Target
flat_bond_target.description: When using the Flat allocation method, this value determines the ratio of bonds in the portfolio

bond_tent_start_allocation.label: Bond Tent Start Allocation
bond_tent_start_allocation.description: When using the bond tent allocation method, this value determines the initial allocation of bonds

bond_tent_start_date.label: Bond Tent Start Date
bond_tent_start_date.description: When using the bond tent allocation method, this value determines the year bond allocation starts to increase

bond_tent_peak_allocation.label: Bond Tent Peak Allocation
bond_tent_peak_allocation.description: When using the bond tent allocation method, this value determines the peak allocation of bonds

bond_tent_peak_date.label: Bond Tent Peak Date
bond_tent_peak_date.description: When using the bond tent allocation method, this value determines the year bond allocation peaks

bond_tent_end_allocation.label: Bond Tent End Allocation
bond_tent_end_allocation.description: When using the bond tent allocation method, this value determines the final allocation of bonds

bond_tent_end_date.label: Bond Tent End Date
bond_tent_end_date.description: When using the bond tent allocation method, this value determines the year bond allocation gets to final default_value

user_social_security_method.label: Your Social Security Method
user_social_security_method.description:
Models the age at which you take social security.
 Early age = 62, mid age = 66, late age = 70.
 Net worth method triggers social security if you haven't met your equity target or at the late age if you have.

partner_social_security_method.label: Partner's Social Security Method
partner_social_security_method.description:
Models the date at which your partner takes social security.
 Early age = 62, mid age = 66, late age = 70.
 Net worth method triggers social security if you haven't met your equity target or at the late age if you have.

pension_trust_factor.label: Pension Trust Factor
pension_trust_factor.description: Many people are skeptical of relying on social security. A value of 0.8 models your social security payment as 80% of what the current social security administration would provide given your earnings record.

user_pension.label: Pension Eligible
user_pension.description: Are you going to receive a pension? If so, social security payment is decreased

partner_pension.label: Partner Pension Eligible
partner_pension.description: Is your partner going to receive a pension? If so, social security payment is decreased

user_earnings_record.label: Your Earnings Record
user_earnings_record.description:
Your historical earnings. This is used to calculate social security payments. 
 Find these records at https://www.ssa.gov/myaccount/

partner_earnings_record.label: Partner's Earnings Record
partner_earnings_record.description:
Historical earnings for partner. This is used to calculate social security payments. 
 Find these records at https://www.ssa.gov/myaccount/
